titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Harold Edward Woodsum, Jr. Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Mary Caldera

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 10:57

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, subject files, reports, meeting minutes, financial records, and other organization files that document Harold Edward Woodsum, Jr.'s terms on the board of directors of the National Audubon Society.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The material in boxes 15-18 is restricted until January 1, 2069 due to the requirements in the donor's deed of gift.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Harold Edward Woodsum, Jr., 1994.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Harold Edward Woodsum, Jr. Papers (MS 1673). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers document Harold Edward Woodsum, Jr.'s terms on the board of directors of the National Audubon Society (NAS). The collection consists of Woodsum's organizational files relating to board business and subject files relating to environmental issues. The files include correspondence to and from other board members, most notably Peter Berle, president of the National Audubon Society. Minutes of meetings, reports, financial records, and files relating to Woodsum's involvement in the annual Birdathon are also included.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Harold Edward Woodsum, Jr. was born on August 13, 1931 in Portland, Maine, the son of Harold Edward Woodsum and Ethel York. He attended Yale University, earning a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1953 and a Bachelor of Laws degree in 1958. He was awarded an honorary Master of Arts degree from Yale in 1979. Woodsum later attended Westbrook College and earned a Doctor of Laws degree in 1991. He was co-founder and partner in the law firm of Drummond, Woodsum, Plimpton McMahon from 1965 to 1988. In 1988, Woodsum became the Director of Athletics of Yale University and remained in that position until 1994. He was elected into the Maine Sports Hall of Fame in 1992. Woodsum is a past trustee of both Yale University and Westbrook College.

A longtime supporter of environmental issues, Woodsum served in several organizations including the Maine Coast Heritage Trust. His thirteen year career in the National Audubon Society began with his election to the board of directors in 1981. He was elected treasurer in 1985 and served as chairman of the board from 1988 to 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of materials created and accumulated by Woodsum while serving on the National Audubon Society (NAS) Board of Directors. The inventory is comprised of one alphabetical listing that incorporates organizational files and subject files. Files documenting the activities of the NAS Board of Directors include correspondence, minutes of meetings, reports, and financial records. Woodsum's correspondence to and from other board members comprises a significant portion of the papers. Correspondence between Woodsum and NAS President Peter Berle is listed under Berle. One folder of personal correspondence is listed at the end of the correspondence files. The files pertaining to Woodsum's participation in the annual Birdathon comprise another significant portion of the organizational files. The Birdathon files include correspondence, pledges, and sponsor lists. Subject files on environmental and conservation issues are interfiled with the organizational files and consist primarily of printed material.

The original arrangement of the files was preserved where possible. Consequently, like materials, i.e. financial records, may be listed under separate headings. Cross-references have been created where appropriate
